http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Stagecraft I is a two-semester course which provides students with both exposure to and experience in all elements of technical theatre, including scenery, props, lighting, sound, costume, and makeup. The four strands emphasize creating, performing/presenting, responding and connecting. In Creating, students generate ideas and original tangible works. In Performing and Presenting, students perform tasks associated with technical theatre and present their work to others. Through Responding, students examine works already created by themselves, their peers, or others to analyze the artistic merit and refine work. Through Connecting, students discover connections between theatrical works and historical, societal, and cultural context. Stagecraft I contains foundational elements of theatre that are not developed in Stagecraft II and III, but the teacher may choose to draw student learning expectations from the Drama II-III Curriculum Framework. Stagecraft II is a two-semester course which allows students to advance their skills in all elements of technical theatre through practical experience, with new instruction in design. Stagecraft III is a two-semester course which allows students to deepen their understanding and advance their skills in specialized elements of technical theatre, which could include scenery, props, lighting, sound, costume, and/or makeup. Stagecraft I fulfills the one-half unit of fine arts credit required for graduation. Arkansas Department of Education approval is not required for Stagecraft I, Stagecraft II, or Stagecraft III.
Creating
Students will generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.

Identify the steps of the design process
  • analysis
  • research
  • preliminary sketches
  • finalized sketches, renderings, or models
  • related paperwork
Explore the collaborative nature of theatre
Create a design morgue
Students will organize and develop artistic ideas and work.

Identify different onstage and offstage theatrical positions
  • actor
  • designer
  • director
  • house manager
  • marketing team
  • playwright
  • producer
  • stage manager
  • technician
and the associated responsibilities

Identify stage directions
  • center stage
  • downstage
  • stage left
  • stage right
  • upstage
Identify the steps in the acting process

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., analysis/research, vocal/movement choices, character choices, rehearsal

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Describe the uses of a variety of theatrical paperwork (e.g., résumé, rehearsal schedule, rehearsal report)
Describe types of documents used for design and execution

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., ground plans, paint elevations, lighting and sound plots, measurement chart, sketch templates, costume and makeup plots, pull lists

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will refine and complete artistic work.
Apply self-reflection and peer feedback to stagecraft work
Performing/Presenting
Students will select, analyze, and interpret artistic work for presentation.
Analyze a script of literary merit to interpret characters and visual/aural design elements

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., setting, time period, given circumstances

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Examine the manner in which character relationships assist in telling the story of a drama/theatre work
Explore multiple sources of information (e.g., print resources, web resources, film, video) to inform design choices

Identify the elements of drama in a drama/theatre work
  • character
  • language
  • plot
  • rhythm
  • spectacle
  • theme
Students will develop and refine artistic work for presentation.
Research technical elements to increase the impact of a presentation
Execute a component of a theatrical design

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., build a set unit, hang/focus light plot, construct a costume piece, style hair, apply makeup

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value:
Identify the steps in the rehearsal process
  • table work
  • blocking
  • working rehearsals
  • tech rehearsals
  • dress rehearsals
  • performance

Differentiate between types of theatre spaces
  • arena
  • black box
  • proscenium
  • thrust

Identify tools and equipment used in scenery and/or property construction
  • construction tools (e.g., saws, drills, hammers, wrenches, pliers)
  • measurement tools (e.g., measuring tape, framing square)
  • painting tools (e.g., brushes, rollers, sponges, stencils)

Identify tools and equipment used in costume construction
  • fasteners
  • iron/steamer
  • measuring tape
  • needles/ pins
  • pattern
  • sewing machine

Identify tools and equipment used in makeup and/or hair styling
  • hair styling tools
  • latex/prosthetics
  • types of makeup
  • wigs
Utilize appropriate safety practices in theatre

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., personal protective equipment, proper use of tools and chemicals, situational awareness, exit procedures

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will convey meaning through the presentation of artistic work.
Describe the manner in which theatrical design (e.g., set design, lighting design, costume design, makeup design) conveys author's intent
Responding
Students will perceive and analyze artistic work.
Discuss dramatic elements of an observed drama/theatre work using basic theatre terminology
Discuss the contribution of technical elements to the effectiveness of a production
Students will interpret intent and meaning in artistic work.
Identify emotional responses evoked by a variety of genres
Students will apply criteria to evaluate artistic work.
Develop criteria using basic theatre terminology to evaluate performances, designs, and/or execution of designs
Differentiate between personal preferences and artistic merit of a drama/theatre work
Connecting
Students will synthesize and relate knowledge and personal experiences to make art.
Analyze the impact of personal experience on the creation of drama/theatre work
Describe the manner in which personal beliefs and biases influence drama/theatre work
Identify various design theories

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., color theory, elements of design, lighting theory

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.
Compare artistic choices with regard to societal, cultural, and historical context
Research historical and cultural context of a drama/theatre work
Distinguish ways in which theatre affects and/or enhances the lives of people of various ages and cultures
Discuss the influence of community values and beliefs in the creation of drama/theatre work

Describe the influence of cultural perspectives and theatrical conventions/practices (e.g., blackout represents passing of time, set with three walls represents an entire room, soliloquy represents character's internal monologue) on theatre
Discuss cultural sensitivity to the artistic work of others
Compare the theatre experience to that of the other arts and media
Identify connections between theatre history and student-developed stagecraft
Identify technological advances in theatre

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., projection, lighting, sound, editing and design software
